explanation:
os_err_name_t — Needed to know whether this typedef is an array type (e.g. char[OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH]) or a pointer; this determines the result of sizeof(*err_name), whether expressions like strncpy(*err_name, ...) and (*err_name)[...] are valid, and how array-to-pointer decay behaves when passed to snprintf.
OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH — The function uses this macro for snprintf and for the final terminator index; the numeric value is required to determine if the strncpy/snprintf calls and the explicit index writes can legally fit within the buffer.
OS_CHECK_POINTER — The macro/check verifies err_name is valid (not NULL) or causes early abort/return; its behavior affects whether subsequent dereferences/indexing of err_name can be assumed safe.
OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t — Required to know the types of its members (particularly Name and Number). Name should be known to be const char * or otherwise, and Number type must match error_num; knowing Name type and typical contents (lengths) is necessary to assess whether copying Error->Name via strncpy can overflow the destination.
OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE and OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE — Need the definitions (types, lengths and content guarantees) to know: how the tables are terminated (Name==NULL sentinel), what string lengths appear in Name entries, and whether any Name strings could exceed the destination buffer.
strncpy — Although a standard lib function, its defined semantics (how it copies/truncates and whether it NUL-terminates) are central to determining if the use here can access/write out-of-bounds, especially combined with the code�s manual termination logic.
snprintf — Its semantics (first argument must be pointer to writable char buffer, second argument is buffer size) are needed to confirm that snprintf(*err_name, OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH, ...) uses a correct buffer pointer and size so no writes beyond the buffer occur.
int32 — The exact typedef of int32 (signed width) is needed only to confirm compatibility with Error->Number and the snprintf format, but include it to validate the cast/format and ensure no undefined behavior related to type mismatch when producing the fallback string.
